comments.comment_body:
The trouble is that instead of taking Trump's words seriously, you are indulging in the typical habit of sneering at Trump.  

Nothing good will happen unless you stop sneering at Trump.

Even more important - saving our oceans!! Phytoplankton comprise less than 1% of plant biomass on earth but unequally contribute nearly HALF (50%!!) of that breathable oxygen. Their distribution and abundance is threatened by anthropogenic climate change too!
They don't call him a bloviator for nothing.

Another step to reducing carbon emissions would be to pass HR 763, the Energy Innovation and Carbon Dividend Act. The bipartisan bill currently has 77 cosponsors in the House of Representatives. It would reduce carbon emissions by 40% by 2030. Call your congressperson and urge them to support HR 763.   For more info: energyinnovationact.org
The President has recommended planting one trillion trees, while he wants the Toongas NF logged.

The nearby college down has been razing wonderful old craftsman-style bungalows to build ugly, poorly built, look-alike apartment buildings and high rise parking lots. It's estimated that over 3000 mature trees were cut down to build these boring apartment buildings. The entire character of a once lovely town has changed with the removal of interesting architecture and the cutting of thousands of mature trees.

Chinese proverb.

"The best time to plant a tree was 20 years ago. The second best time is now."

This is true, but as Margaret Renkl writes, a sapling is no substitute for a mature tree.  The work an older tree does to cool and clean the planet is priceless. This is urgent.  I believe policy 
should be written to protect established trees and forests around the world.   I am a certified arborist.  It takes no time at all to remove a centuries old tree.  It'll take hundreds of years to replace it.  We don't have that kind of time.

We selected and purchased our house in large part because the backyard was filled with trees. The trees were old and had been part of a tree line of a farm, long gone. We started losing them shortly after we moved in. Lightening strikes, disease and lawn care choices made by the previous owners took a huge toll. We went from 12 trees down to 1. I have replanted as we lost, but it will be years before my trees are the size of the originals. As I watch similar losses throughout my neighborhood, residents are not replacing the trees. Each loss breaks my heart. At our former home, we had two beautiful massive maple trees in the back yard. The new owners wasted no time having them removed. We need a massive education to convince people to keep what they have, and plant more.

My family lives on some acreage about 10 miles east of Asheville, NC. We watch, almost daily now as developers clear cut forests so that people can have 360 degree mountain views. The developers get tax incentives for this behavior, if they slap an affordable unit or two in (which isn't really very affordable...) Meanwhile, those of us who haven't sold out to developers bear the brunt of everyone else's mountain views and don't get any tax incentives. It is time to start rewarding property owners in highly developing areas for NOT selling to developers. They are forming an increasingly important line in the fight against climate change.

Let me get this straight - a TRILLION trees?

The world population is approximately 7 BILLION people. 

 A trillion is a thousand billion ... or approximately 140,000 trees for every man, woman and child on planet earth. Is this CRAZY or is this crazy???

For one thing, where would we find the room to plant them and what would have to be replaced to make the room in the first place?

I'm going to go out on a limb here and suggest that maintaining the old mature trees may not be the best way to go forward. In their superior adaptation to the environment, they have been able to sequester huge amounts of carbon. What  if we were to log the old trees, (put people to work),mill the lumber (put people to work), build affordable housing (put people to work), weatherize existing buildings (put people to work), and in the mean time, plant 2,3,4,trees for each one we cut down that would potentially sequester more carbon than the mature trees we were to harvest, thereby not releasing their carbon.  I have been a resident of Oregon for 48 years (part time now). I have seen the beauty of and experienced the higher power of the old growth    forest, but I have also seen the regeneration of the burned forest and the replanted forests enough to know that we need to focus on all aspects of our environment if we are to survive . The earth is a complex system which gives us many options to pursue. 
PS i'm proud to say that my wife and I have planted hundreds of trees in our lifetime.

I live in a 1900 historic home on 1/3 acre in the middle of Denver.  The house sits surrounded by #13 mature varied trees: even a thriving old elm. I bought the house for the trees.  The yard is unlike anything I have seen in Denver, with visiting hawks, fox, rabbits, owls, coyotes, raccoon and a multitude of birds. (even a female bald eagle came for breakfast once day) But realtors have assured me that any developer will demolish the house, clear every tree, and most likely build two "box houses" given the market here. The landmark commission has denied my request for preservation.  I hope when the time comes, a lovely family will fall in love with these trees just as I did.

Trump is not proposing saving trees nor reducing burning hydrocarbons, he's just pretending that planting trees will offset the deforestation and great burning of fossil fuels to make American great again. Silly but it keeps him popular with the Republicans who cannot grasp how the biosphere relates to themselves.
What’s better?  How about if all my neighbors clean up all the leaves around their properties by about Thanksgiving?  Including in the streets by their houses.

Who will speak for the trees, that are already there, mature, sustaining of so much wildlife and habitat?   It must be us.   Save a trillion of these amazing trees; prevent their destruction.   If we think common sense, that is what we must do.   It is so silly and ridiculous to suggest that planting tiny shoots now could ever hope in real time to make up for the elimination of one trillion mature trees now.   That is our realistic challenge then; preventing the destruction of one trillion existing trees.  We each know where they are; let’s get going to protect them.

What's really ridiculous is how infrequently the New York Times places articles about climate change in prominent positions. It is devastatingly clear that climate change is the greatest issue we face, and yet coverage generally continues to be relegated to a marginal section of the paper. We should be hearing about this loud and clear, every single day.

We need to do the obvious: plant a gazillion trees, build hundreds of power plants, and move the world away from an animal-based diet to one that is plant-based and lab-meat/fish based. Everything else is just commentary. When I ask my lefty friends about nuclear power, they blanch. Then I tell them that France gets 70 percent of its electricity from nuclear, and they think I'm lying. But I'm not. Look it up.

The essential message here is SAVE the maturing trees that exist! Older trees sequester more carbon, provide habitat, and offer beauty. Read Wild Carbon at the Northeast Wilderness Trust website. northeastwildernesstrust.org

What's better than planting a trillion trees?

Getting rid of Trump so the EPA can get back to doing its job.  But now the EPA has much more work to do than ever, since Trump has set the environment back dramatically. 

Wetlands, once despoiled and with mature trees cut, vegetation uprooted and wildlife decimated may never be able to be restored.  Certainly not if people begin building on it.  Yes, you can landfill wetlands because much of federal wetlands are smaller areas with streams, springs, creeks that can be landfilled and homes built.  In NY State the larger wetlands are protected by NY State, not the feds.  Those deeper waters are not buildable anyway, though they might be subjected to pollution, of course.  Federal wetlands are smaller but just as critical for clean water and the natural environment.  This is why what Trump is doing is so evil.  It's PERMANENT destruction of key parts of our environment.  Trump is nothing short of a disaster! 

Not only must we have a Democrat in the White House next year, we also need a Democratic majority in the Senate and the House.  

Getting rid of Trump is the most important goal for America and the world in 2020.

Planting trees is a wonderfully optimistic activity. However so many trees won't make it to middle age as that they were grown badly by the nurseries and then planted badly by professionals and non-professionals alike. For expediency nurseries bury the root-flare as they grow the tree for sale and then the root-flare is NEVER exposed and planted at the level of the ground around it's "forever home". A tree can't make it if it's grown and planted badly.

Take care of the ones that Mother Nature has nurtured since they were seeds. Preserve our forests. If you do plant: know what you're doing.
I picture the planet covered with trees planted in rows. When planting is done, there seems to be no thought given. When it comes to the actual landscape, there is no landscaping.

How about reducing meat eating? Most forests cleared due to cattle, 1/3 agriculture water for cattle.  Reducing eating meat by 30% would save an area of forest as big as California each year. If we continue to demand meat  (we now eat 280 lbs per person per year) by 2059 almost all forests gone.
while I agree with nearly everything you say in this piece , temperature extremes, storms , floods and droughts are the hallmark of weather. climate is different

I don't listen to Trump's speeches not just because of the gross lack of intelligence, but also because he doesn't mean a word he says.

Did you see the report at the end of January, based on documents FOIA'ed by Earthjustice.org, that the U.S. Forest Service is using U.S. taxpayer monies to pay lumber companies to log Alaska's Tongass National Forest? The Alaska Wilderness League describes the Tongass as "one of the last remaining intact temperate rainforests in the world."

Just like Nashville's legislation "doesn’t impose any penalties on builders who choose not to preserve those heritage trees," Trump's trillion tree commitment is hot air.

Oh, by the way, after a lifetime in Manhattan, I moved upstate to my ancestors' a 100-acre tree farm. The job of caretaking a forest is daunting. I'd like to have as many employees as there are acres to tend it. Seedlings take dedicated, individualized TLC to flourish.

If we could shift our economic focus from nurturing dead dinosaurs (i.e. coal, oil & gas) to nurturing things that grow from and on the Earth (including humans), what a beautiful, breathtaking place the U.S. would be.

One Sunday afternoon in 1995, as a pastor in rural Missouri, I went calling on an elderly couple who lived in an old two story farmhouse on a hill looking over the "front 40" (acres).  The long driveway ended in a small crosswise loop in front of the house.  Inside each end of the loop grew a single massive white oak tree, no doubt planted when the house and driveway were constructed.  I estimated everything to be about 80 years old.  An oak tree that grows in open sunlight for 80 years in good soil can become a big tree.

Always the local history buff, and chatting with my parishoners later over tea and cookies inside the home, I asked the husband and weathered old farmer Jasper if he knew anything about those gigantic oak trees in front of the house.  He said, "Well, they weren't that big when my father and I planted them."

We need to start thinking in the United States like our ancestors did.  They planned 100 years ahead, and so must we.

Planting a trillion trees sounds like a good idea, much better that stopping oil and gas exploration.  It is hard to treat global warming very seriously when the plans do not include nuclear energy or even planting trees.  Why Did Jane Goodall have to bring it up.

Global warming is a political tool designed to redistribute wealth rather than cure some type of real world problem.  It is based on the notion that poor people are somehow more affected by global warming than others, despite the fact that the proponents of solution say the entire world will end in 10 years if we don't completely redo our entire world.

Even this article belittles the trillion tree planting.  The article says it is OK but will not solve the problem.  The position would make some sense if it were backed up with some data.  There is no estimate mentioned what would happen if the trillion tree planting is made, only a statement it isn't enough.

The proponents of radical changes to cure global warming really don't say much that makes sense.  I remember being told in the past that the world would turn colder and that we were in a warm period of earth history.  Whatever is happening, if anything, I like planting trees but don't want to throw anyone out of work by stopping oil and gas exploration.

As with the pleasant guest offering career advice to Benjamin Braddock in the film The Graduate, so will I offer an overlooked solution.  While planting a Trillion trees, may we also plant HEMP?  No more worries about clearcutting for toilet paper in Canada.  And many other products will ensue including clothing, car interiors, and upholestry.  Trees and Hemp are valuable and needed.

Whether one trillion trees, or ten trillion trees - planting them will have no long term effect on climate change.

Any carbon they pull from the atmosphere goes returns after they die, and are decomposed by microbes in soil. The Earth's biocycle, air to plants to animals back to air again, has been repeating for tens of millions of years with no significant variation in atmospheric carbon.

That cycle was upset in the middle of the nineteenth century, when we started extracting oil and coal from deep underground and burned them for fuel. The only way to slow the disaster of climate change is to end the combustion of fossil fuel.

Leave it in the ground.

Contrary to perception Trumps changes to environmental policy will little effect the environment. Pollution laws are not being "gutted". The difference would hard to measure in air and water quality.
 Of course fossil fuel burning must be curtailed.. worldwide. The only way to do it is nuclear. All out research on next generation reactors capable of being set up in 3rd world countries is the potential solution. Countries around the world are advancing rapidly, they will burn fossil fuel to do so if the only option is solar,wind,batteries. Our carbon reductions are being dwarfed by increases in advancing poor countries.

On public lands in the Western states, the Bureau of Land Management is engaged in "vegetation management" projects on hundreds of thousands of acres of public lands,  which involve the complete destruction of millions of full-grown pinyon and juniper trees, many hundreds of years old. The rationale offered is that removing these native trees will create more forage, almost all of which is used by grazing cattle. I guess the plan is to subsidize the destruction of western high desert forests, and then have the taxpayers foot the bill for replanting the same forests in decades to come. What a world!

Someone should confirm reports China has planted 67 billion trees and continues planting about 12 billion per year. Their latest project according to one report I read is a massive undertaking of tree planting in their deserts. I think this is being done mostly by their Army, which might be a good reason to stop our foreign wars.

Large trees store large amounts of carbon, and these larger trees are typically more predominant on public property (such as parks and state and National Forests), as opposed to privately held woodlots. Last year Trump issued an executive order to the U. S. Forest Service to increase logging on National Forests by 25 percent! This is insanity, particularly in the face of a rapidly changing
climate. Required coordinated and enforceable land use planning could go a long way towards protecting our vital forests. Additionally, developers should be mandated to take into account, through avoidance, substantial groves of large trees in their initial development plans. It can be done! And potential buyers desire it!

The point about "mono-culture" resonates with me as I look at row upon, neatly planted, but stunted, row of CCC trees planted here in Northern Michigan.  It's not natural and I never see any wildlife in those "forests" and they've been growing for 90 years now.

The trees have been cut down in Mashpee, MA, on Cape Cod, at an alarming rate. I wish someone would do an investigation into who has benefitted financially from the rapacious and horrifying deforestation of recent years. From the shops at Mashpee Common - which now cover acres and acres of what used to be scrub pine and open land - to the former "common areas" within the development called New Seabury (owned by Carl Icahn and stripped at a horrifying rate since he became involved...), the forests of Mashpee are being completely lost. No effort has been made to preserve anything, the zoning laws are useless, entire forest tracts, there forever, have just been clear cut. Why does the Mashpee town council allow this? Who is making money? Who are the developers? The ecosystem cannot be replaced once destroyed, and for nothing more than another Dunkin Donuts or other ugly, useless, unnecessary commercial outlet. Please look into this and help save this area! Planting trees is fine but we should not be cutting down so many to begin with! Thank you!

Trump said the US will join the Trillion Tree initiative ... but actually joining and contributing are different from saying.  Trump has shown no interest in any conservation/preservation ideas ... what makes you think he has actually changed his mind?
A trillion trees, a trillion dollar deficit. Trillions mean nothing to Trump.
What is better than planting a trillion trees, getting rid of climate deniers in the GOP. Save our planet vote them out in November. We and our planet deserve better, our lives depend on it.

Everyone on both sides of the climate crisis debate agree that increasing catastrophes are real, devastating, and heartbreaking but why are these things happening. THAT IS THE QUESTION THAT DEMANDS AN ANSWER? Yes, people are destroying the earth and Revelation 11:18 states that when Jesus finally drops the curtain on human sin, waywardness, and rebellion, He will destroy those who destroy the earth.. the technology was already there for automobiles to run on water decades ago but the automobile companies would have had to retool and that would have cost too much, so here we are, as a result of loving money, at the end of the world. The powers that be will very soon declare that men are offending God by the violation of the Sunday sabbath, that this sin has brought calamities that will not cease until Sunday shall be enforced by law. But Sunday is not the Sabbath it is Saturday, so we will all have a choice SOON follow the pope who is asking for a Sunday law to solve the climate crisis - see his book Laudato Si. Or, follow Jesus who kept the Biblical day of worship Saturday, Luke 4:18. If we follow Jesus we will likely be martyred as He was, but when He returns we will be granted eternal life with Him in paradise.

Won't this cost money? Won't this too be cut out of the budget?  Maybe we can convince trump that the trees can be used for a military purpose.   Or it can be used to retaliate against (choose a state that did not support the orange man)
Promise to plant a trillion trees, you'll be written about for a week. Invest a trillion in solar and wind, you'll be written about for generations as the president who saved trillions of trees.

In the western US, the worst thing you could do is plant a bunch of tree seedlings. Our problem is too many skinny little trees and  not enough tall, thick-barked, fire resistant old trees. What we need is intelligent management of the trees we already have and  a prison cell for the executives of Exxon, BP and all the companies who knew what their product was doing to the planet and kept drilling anyway.

Population growth beyond the Earth's capacity is the fundamental cause.  And it is arguably too late to recover from this cancer of the planet.  There is, in processes, a phenomenon known as the tipping point, past which the process cannot be halted, and the Earth's population is well past that, reached it probably 40 years ago.

Anybody who was a participant in the creation of more than one child -- two, maybe, for a two adult pair -- has no claim whatsoever to urge others to conserve.  If you did so:  You, personally, are responsible for the Earth's demise, and your supposed support of halting climate change is pure hypocrisy. 

The idea that abortion is to be restricted -- in some views, eliminated -- is ludicrous.  Rather, pregnancy should be restricted, available only by permit, and any unlicensed pregnancy terminated, by law.

China has tried to implement such a policy; it is close to working there.  It must be a global policy, particularly among the poorest regions where large families are the standard, and enforced even against those claiming it interferes with their belief system.  Freedom of religion is no excuse; indeed, those faiths supporting unlimited family growth must have their religion-based attitude outlawed -- literally, their preaching against population control and forbidding their flock access to abortion made a punishable offense, up to outlawing the faith's existence.  We outlawed polygamy; we can -- and must -- outlaw unsanctioned childbirth.
For every five trees cut in the Amazon, we'll plan one...  where, exactly?
Basically, the basic problem is: overpopulation.

Will Trump have the State Department negotiate to free up the thousands of square miles needed to plant a trillion trees? Or will he ask for billions of dollars to fund it then, when Brazil refuses, reallocate the money to build his wall?

I'd feel better about saving an existing billion trees than about planting a trillion new ones. Others have pointed out how it's all about population. There we run into a classic problem, as long as sex is more popular than death.
Unless this effort results in native woodland ecosystem restorations this is just more Lipstick on the Trump Administration to fool the uninformed voting masses.
No Trump is simple-minded and unable to understand the environment. It is like trying to teach him a foreign language. He cannot learn it. Don't waste your time.

And in Siberia they wish to resurrect the Wooly Mammoth to knock down the trees that are making he permafrost in theTundra melt.
They need grasses and buffalo apparently.

What's better than planting a trillion trees?
Electing a new president and congressional representatives who are better stewards of humanity and the environment. 

Vote Blue.

I guess they are going to plant all those trees along the US-Mexican border.
Build the wall?  No. Grow the wall.

Margaret Renki is one Environmentalist I can fully agree with and support. She is NOT a Envrionment Nazi. Kudos to her. 
We need more common sense and truth telling Environmentalists and not the kinds of like Alexandria Occasio Cortez who are extremeist  and have no knowledge base to boot. There are others also in the scientific Community who want to protect the environment but are so extreme that they turn off people like me who absolutely and sincerely support protecting our environment even if we have to sacrifice some thing to protect it.
LET US ABSOLUTELY PROTECT OUR ENVIRONMENT BUT LET US ALSO BE SENSIBLE ABOUT IT.
It is top-tier insanity that the loser would (weird-)flex about a trillion trees while being buddies with Brazil's Amazon-killer, the generally insane jailable bolsonaro.

Q: What's better than planting a trillion trees?

A:  Getting rid of Donald Trump.
THE 1 thing better than planting a trillion trees:  getting rid of trump.
I love this column.

Why do people use these idiotic numbers? One trillion trees equals planting almost 14,000 each day, every day, since the year George Washington died, 1819. Think about that next time you hear the word "trillion."

What’s better than planting sextillion trees?
Saving the oceans.
Completely overlooked by many is the truth that most of the CO2 to breathable O2 that keeps us alive process is carried out at sea - by seriously threatened blue-green algae and cyanobacteria living in the first inches of the 2/3rds of the planet’s surface that is water, mainly ocean.
If the ocean gas converters die - every bit of life except a few anaerobic bacteria and viruses that do not need oxygen breathing hosts, goes too.
Land plants creating the oxygen they need may hang on for a while, but multicellular life will have had it.
Some of us might last a while, with solar-powered systems splitting water into hydrogen and oxygen - until the food runs out.
And what is the US Government doing? Allowing more raw sewage to pour into our rivers, down to the seas.
The rest of the world doesn’t seem too interested either: a minor (compared to say with the 14th Century Plague or the flu pandemic of the early 1900s) is getting UN attention - but the General Assembly is not likely to pass a resolution banning poisoning of the seas or atmosphere - though it threatens the near-complete annihilation of life on the only planet we call home.

FDR proposed planting lines of trees across the country to keep fields from blowing away in the Dust Bowl. It's just good property management. Maybe that's the way our Golf Course Kind sees this. In which case, the more complicated ecosystem is almost certain to elude him.

My husband and I lost eleven trees a few years ago to a combination of freak storms, microbursts and the electric company.  Two remaining specimens - 100-foot middle age scarlet oaks - remain standing very close to the house.  One is leaning at the edge of my kitchen roof and after all the stress of previous storms I decided I couldn’t live with it anymore.  I’d already been told it might have disease and ought to come down.  We made the decision but didn’t set a date, deep down knowing what we were planning was wrong on some level.  

It got to the point where I would hush my husband if he talked about cutting it within ‘earshot’ if the tree.  I mean, it’s a living thing.  How do we know what it understands?  

And then something miraculous happened.  I contacted a young, sought-after arborist to get a cut estimate and this man spent time inspecting the tree.  He then gently began advocating for it.  “It’s showing signs of age, yes, but it’s healthy for its age, etc.”  (I’m middle age myself, so, yeah, I get it.) 

In a few weeks time this tree-whisperer will come trim dead branches from my trees, possibly lighten the canopies slightly to better resist wind.  In the spring we will fertilize & treat natural canker... it’s silly but knowing all this I feel at peace - more than having a yard full of sawdust could ever achieve.  

One day the trees may actually be dying and come down (one way or another) but in the meantime we’ll be living side by side and I’m grateful.

Of course there is no ecological conversion with Trump only a cynical plow to nibble a few votes away from undecided with a speech he did not even write.  
Since his withdrawal from the climate accord he has fought the efforts of states to maintain efforts on their part to cut emissions and encouraged countries around the world to ignore the demon of climate change.
He has no plan at all other than to increase production and green house gases across the country.  That and to win an election at all costs and if that means deceitful tricks so be it.  And oh yes profits and more quarterly earnings.
A quadrillion trees would have even been better. Allowing 4 square meters per tree, a trillion trees would take 40% of the area of US.

Why plant seedlings, or stop mowing excess lawns and leave them to natural succession? For those aware of the fact of global warming, taking such steps confronts and overcomes depression.  Depression in the face of the world warming in process and about to overwhelm those who follow us, I believe, explains much of the denial we see as well as the absence of political action by those who, at some level of consciousness, accept the fact of global warming.  Know and face that depression.  Act. Plant seedlings where possible; contribute to equatorial reforestation if you have no land available.  Let your children select the seedling(s) and digging; or let them decide what tree planting  entity (there are scads) gets your money.  Children are the ones who must live with what we do or not do.

Having lived in Florida, I know that one can exist even in the summer without air conditioning as long as there is shade. 

Yet, developers always start new housing by clear cutting the lot of all trees. It would be perfectly feasible to make a canopy preservation plan part of the permitting process yet it is never done. 

One of the  problems is that it makes more sense to sell to the public expensive housing by front loading the savings in building costs while back loading the price with expensive air conditioning bills. The culprit is the mortgage payment which is used to qualify borrowers. 

Common sense regulation of the building/mortgage business would do a lot for saving our canopy.

Start a “ Notable Trees of the Neighborhood”  campaign.  Get your local community involved in finding notable trees, posting locations and descriptions along with advocating for rules against cutting down the “ notables” without community consent. It can be a school project.   Here in Chicago many old oaks that “ saw “ buffalo are still here, on knolls, along ridges, and where settlements or trails once were. It wasn’t really that long ago. 
I might be getting old but the appreciation of trees has only increased as I’ve aged. Nice to know they’ll carry on after one has departed the scene.
Yes, save the forests we have.  Saplings can take decades to mature.  We don't have decades.

“ it would be a conversion narrative more potent than any since St. Paul “

Trump is no Paul.  He’d harvest every tree in the world and burn the slash if he had the chance. 

Avoiding deforestation and putting a price on carbon are more important than planting. Every planted tree needs an experienced planter and some attention the first few years to survive. Allowing existing trees and forests to thrive will sequester more carbon faster.  Of course, planting is great in well regulated situations.
If the human population does not get smaller, there will be NO trees left to save.  The breeding habits of humans have taken over the earth.  Coronavirus is welcome; bring on more diseases like it.

How about we just pay the folks living in the Amazon, the Phillipines, and Indonesia to protect their trees?  In effect, instead of them burning plots to make room to grow crops they farm the trees themselves?

The dismissal of planting trees without asserting that natural habitats being destroyed represent not just lost plants but animals and ecological systems which just planting any old thing cannot replace or restore is like the argument that the solution to global warming is population reduction. Not reasonable. 

The planting of trees and plants will take carbon dioxide out of the air, and the concentration of carbon gases is diminished. It's how nature removes carbon dioxide from the air since before any hominid existed. Planting trees addresses that problem.

We have another big catastrophe which is a mass extinction which man has instigated and should endeavor to stop. The loss of species will diminish our biosphere and will affect us profoundly over time. We have so many people on the Earth that is straining our natural world's ability to support all the life as we use up resources. But the global warming process began when our population was far less than a billion people and it's over seven billion today. Reducing human population numbers will affect some strains but global warming is a different proposition.

I live in the Midwest, specifically the area known as the Great Plains. I love trees...I should say I love native trees. We have had to cull our ash trees because of an invasive species. The emerald ash borer came from Asia. 

What if we are not helping the environment but actually harming it by adding trees. Hear me out! Just like stripping the Amazon and burning the Rainforest, could we be harming the planet by adding trees in areas that should not have trees. The planet is being terraformed by our attempts to save the planet. 

Totally unprove, not well thought out, hypothesis.

I think Trump just liked using the word trillion.  Trillion trees, trillion dollar deficit, seeking trillion likes for Trump's tweets.   There is probably no money in his budget for this.  But if sounds good to voters, like his support for coverage of pre-existing conditions, he will simply proclaim it.  Another con job.

What about reducing America's insatiable appetite for unsustainable, disease-inducing foods like meat, chicken, and dairy by taxing it heavily? Use the tax to restore the land. Methane from cows and their waste is not only decimating the climate but also the environment.

There is a 440 acre woods in the middle CT's most populous city, Bridgeport.  It's called Remington Woods.  It's owner a private company is attempting to "develop" it this year.  A citizen group Preserve Remington Woods is opposing the idea hoping to preserve the trees and lake and wetlands.  See and support www.PreserveRemingtonWoods.com

As Ms. Renkl notes it takes decades before a seedling will grow into a tree that will sequester any noticeable amount of carbon.  We don't have decades.   We have just ten years before the first huge hurdle, cutting back carbon emissions by 50%

1 tril. trees? Too late.
130+ comments & only 2-3 touch on the cause of current & future exponential global warming: the 220 prior years of digging up the carbon that earth took 4+ bil. years to sequester, and burning it for exponentially needed energy.
Why? To support an exponential human population now at 7.4 bil. 
In 2012, the biologist E.O. Wilson hit the nail on the head: In homo Sapiens' entire 400K history, he has never used his tech advances to control his numbers. 
In my lifetime, US & world pop. have tripled. So much for birth control tech. 
And for what economic/tech benefit that the world's then 2.5 billion could not have provided, if it stayed stable?
Most countries today officially call themselves "underpopulated".
Only one country to date has tried to limit its population by state policy. Even with the great advantage of an intrusive, autocratic, dictatorship, the multi-year policy, based on census figures, only slowed growth, and is today considered a stability failure. Good luck, China.
Name one world religion for pop. stability.
There's no existing theoretical science for capturing & then sequestering the prior 220 years of released carbon. If discovered, then comes the testing stage; then the scale up stage. 
Good luck, world, while pop. doubles & doubles again, all needing massive energy. A race vs. earth?

Undoubtedly ensuring that the existing trillion trees in Amazons remain intact. 

There is a simple rational for that. As we saw in Australia, existing trees come with trillions of animals, insects, and all kinds of vegetations.  Planted trees initially come alone.

85% don't survive may not mean what it seems to imply.

Young trees take a smaller space, less area. As they grow, they need more. A very common way to plant trees is to plant a great density of small trees, then thin them in a few years so the most promising have more room to grow, and then keep thinning them as they grow. Thin half twice and you have taken out 75%, common by the time they reach a very middling size at second thinning, maybe 15 years after planting.

If you don't thin them, then they thin themselves. The same numbers die, and often the same trees since they self select for promising dominant trees the same as we do, but they are not as efficient. It takes longer to resolve the struggle so, and they can damage the good trees as they die and come down.

As for carbon, all this is a good thing. Wood grows, and carbon is absorbed, according to the density of the canopy, not the numbers of trees in that canopy. Big healthy trees will take up as much carbon, and hold it longer, than a struggling overcrowded woodland in which the trees are choking each other.

Density of canopy is important to total carbon in trees. Tree grow upward, and hold more carbon per unit area, only when they need to grow upward to reach the light. A low spreading tree may be nice shade and pretty, but it does not have a towering trunk holding lots of carbon, just spreading roots and branches. Therefore scattered shade trees are not the same as a full woodland.

It is difficult to talk about the deficit & taxes when most people don't understand how the finances of the federal gov work. A reader, max, said in a reply to one of my comments:

"So much of our economic issues could be solved if people understood that the US cannot run out of money, and how hard it is to cause hyperinflation from government spending alone."

Let me show that max got it right.

First gov operations, militarily, infrastructure, etc. are NOT paid for or limited by taxes or borrowing.

The gov doesn't need your money. It can (thru the FED) create as much as it needs out of thin air. Unless you have a printing press in your basement, you can't do that.

But there's a catch. If the gov needs to create too much money to do the things we want it to do, we may not be able to make enough stuff to soak that money up & will have too much money chasing not enough stuff, i.e. excessive inflation.

But that's easy to solve & where taxes come in. Taxes allow the gov to take back the excess money & prevent inflation. 

The purpose of taxes is to adjust the amount of money in the economy.

Now if production is constrained say by a shortage of oil, we may not be able to tax enough. That's we we get hyperinflation.

Since federal spending sends money to us & taxes take it back, the deficit is just the net amount of money the gov sends to the private sector & the debt is just the algebraic sum of all the money the gov has sent over time.

Understand this, and we can talk.

Think about that:  People resisted technology so they could continue toiling fields from dusk till dawn; They opposed automation because they wanted to continue riding down into the depths to mine coal in the most dangerous conditions imaginable for a pittance in wages.

Why?  Why would people fight to continue a life of debilitating labor and to live like serfs?

The reason should be clear:  People are fearful of losing their livelihood because the current system all but ensures that the benefits of labor-saving technology do not flow to the laborers, but instead accrue to the capital owning class. 

I, for one, embrace a future where humans are unchained from the shackles of work.  But to get there we must also move beyond requiring work as condition for economic security.  Otherwise we are looking towards a dystopian future that turns us back centuries to the dark ages of feudalism and serfdom.

There is an alternative path, less dystopian and more Utopian, but this path demands that we start working towards a universal basic income for all.
