The fee is the same whether you paid $20 or $200 and this adds up unless you can pay a large sum of money all at once.  So she brought her lunch and always packed a couple extra snacks to share with a friend who might still be hungry.

However, that said, she is now in community college and the lunches there cost twice as much and not as good. She still brings her lunch and eats much healthier and uses the money she saves on other expenses.

My mother, who is Italian born and raised, would pack my lunch every day. It was as likely to be a salami sandwich on thick Italian bread as it could have been PB&J or some other typical American fare.

If you want to rely on the school to feed your kids, so be it. That said, I wish everyone had a parent like my mom!

The quality of the school lunches at the elementary school where I teach is questionable.  While they meet the nutritional guidelines of the federal lunch program, the food is not necessarily appetizing and often my students groan when the menu is read in the morning.  One of the big problems with food waste is simple...many of the fruits offered are too difficult for the students to eat.  One morning I noticed a young girl about to throw away a whole orange.  When I asked her about it, she said she was unable to peel it.  The tips of her fingernails did not extend above her finger tips.  Whole apples and bananas have also found their way into the trash can either because they were too difficult to eat or were simply not appetizing to children.

Portions for all students were fairly standardized with smaller and younger students receiving the same portions as some of the older and larger students.  I had many of my older students complain of being hungry later in the afternoon.

While I agree it would have been nice not to send lunch with my kid (he is in college now) the reality was that the food was terrible, the time period allowed for lunch so brief that if he stood in line to get lunch, he wouldn't have time to eat.  I did a quick check online at the current lunch menu at his old school:  For today the menu was Chicken & Waffles, PB & J Smuckers, Oranges, Fruit Cup, Salad Bar.  My recall of salad bar was - iceberg lettuce, a few carrot shreds and ranch dressing.  The ingredients for Chicken & Waffles are a long list of unpronounceable items that I don't normally use in my cooking.  Not exactly what I think is a great lunch.   Sending lunch allowed my son to eat what he liked, healthy items and treats and eat before lunch time ran out.

Wonderful to see these advancements which have been advocated by so many ever since the days when the Regan administration tried to categorize ketchup as a vegetable. (And thanks, Michelle Obama!) Giving your kid the autonomy to pack their own lunch (maybe 2nd or 3rd grade) is a great way to build self-esteem and teach responsibility.  

Luckily, my kids attend a Catholic school that doesn't even have a cafeteria.  They will have packed lunches at least until 8th grade.

The lunches at Texas public schools are not very good, are expensive (especially if you have more than 1 child), and are mostly processed food. Now that Trump has decided to interfere I am sure they will get worse. We are now free to believe that catsup is a vegetable.
Packed lunches for my kids for the same reason I cook every night and make my dog's food.....I know what's going into the meal. Organic, no GMO's, no farmed fish, no gluten......that's why.

There is no subtext to a mother wanting to make lunch for her child, and there is no need to refer specifically to affluent women who have the means and time. The reason my kids bring lunch is right there in every photo in this article.....styrofoam.  Schools generate mountains of trash every day, and with the all the cuts to personnel having a dishwasher and reusable trays is out of the question.
School lunch and breakfast should be free for all. Then we wouldn't need to opt-in to keep it running.

We pack lunch, usually frozen dinners, for our kids because school food costs too much. I am intimately familiar with our school lunches and the saddest part for me is the pre-fab entrees.  Nothing is made from scratch on-site, so it is cardboard food that comes in plastic bags from somewhere, ready to heat up.

Green Apples hard as rocks, sourced we presume because they were cheap. Tables of children attempting to cut into the rock-hard Green Apples with plastic spoons and forks.  Title 1 schools take the hardest nutritional HIT.
My kids never ate the packed lunch or the school lunch. Very frustrating. I would at least stock their backpacks with peanuts, granola bars, cheese sticks and hope for the best.

Each picture shows cow's milk. Cows milk is for infant cows. Neither of my school age children are now infants, and I'm fairly certain they are not cows and therefore don't need to drink cows milk. 

Until there are plant based meals available. We will continue to make lunches at home.

It is amazing that schools have to be an educational institute, daycare, physical health facility, special education facility, and provide breakfast and lunch for students. We are fine packing a lunch!

This is my children's school district and the menu has gotten progressively better each year. School food lunch programs have gotten much better over the years thanks to President Obama and Michelle Obama. I was a former pubic school principal, superintendent and state Secretary of Education in VT and saw first hand the improvements in quality of our school lunches. Yes, the first few years of providing salad bar stations, more veggies, and less fried food for young children were rocky, but students soon got used to it. Some of our schools were also very open to experimenting with new and unusual healthy foods for children to try before putting them on the menu. I remember food service staff trying out frog legs for students, which was not implemented but it gave students an opportunity to try a new type of food.
As Secretary of Education working with food service directors, I proposed free lunches for all students as a way of increasing participation and ending the free lunch/reduced lunch stigma some students experienced. Unfortunately, we were not successful in making all lunches free but we were able to qualify for free lunches for anyone who was eligible for a reduced lunch.  I am an advocate for free breakfast and lunch for all children as a way of Increasing participation of school lunches which will improve the quality of food for all children.
There are many reasons parents may choose to pack lunches for their children, but quality of the lunches should not be the driving issue.
My kids ask for homemade lunches, even as teens. It’s kind of a pain and yet a privilege -and the least I can do to squeeze in some TLC. They’ll be off and gone before I know it.

Why are we still serving our kids lowfat and skim milk as shown in the lede's photo?  Instead of worrying about fat (debunked theory, see: Gary Taubes, "Good Calories, Bad Calories"), shouldn't we be much more concerned with the hormones and antibiotics administered to the commercial feedlot cows and the feed consisting of predominantly GMO corn and soy (sprayed with tons of glyphosate-laden pesticides) that the cows eat?

I packed lunch for my kids when they were growing up but I would have really appreciated freedom from this chore since I was studying and working at the time. But looking at the lunches on this page, I know I would never let my kids eat these food-like substances. There is no need for kids to drink reduced-fat milk (or any milk at all) and sugary juice. Burgers for lunch? My kids had burgers once a month as a treat. But even if there was French-quality food in the school cafeteria, why should I pay more for my kids’ lunches so that other children should get theirs for free? Either provide free food (and I mean food, not burgers and fries) for everybody or make everybody pay.
You could try to make it a universal benefit. Rather than shaming people into paying for it you would tax them. Means tested services tend to be inferior.

Some of our kids come home for lunch with relatives who are retired.  They have home cooking which is healthy and they eat it . On rainy days they have a healthy sandwich 
No I don’t want strangers feeding my children because there really is no trust.
When I read about schools shaming students because they don’t have money for the lunches it shamed me as American we can have so much and deprive little ones. Worried about money let a Wall Street hedge fund manager care for specific school zip codes then everyone eats well
Till they do something besides shaming little ones our child will eat at home

This is completely dependent on where you live, how much money the school district has, and how many kids in the district qualify for free or reduced lunch.

Having lived in a wealthy suburban district - where my kid and almost every other kid - ate school lunch and then relocating to a larger school district, I can promise you that the differences in quality are huge.

In the past year or so I have read about how truly awful many of our schools are with overcrowded, unsafe, inadequate buildings and out-of-date teaching materials. I also learned that way too many of our teachers actually buy the materials because their school system is too poor to function well. 

The school lunch stories only add to the horror of what this nation has allowed to happen to our children. The message is that we don't value their minds or their health or the systems that have the task of teaching them.

I am old and discouraged that our national values are so distorted by fear, greed, and lack of caring about the future. It is true that what we have done quarantees unequal, difficult and unhappy futures for our children and grandchildren unless they are rich. 

Maybe the destruction or death of the planet will resolve all these issues.

If parents want to pack their kids a school lunch, for heavens sake let them.  Please don't try to make it a not-politically-correct choice.  Who wouldn't prefer their parent's cooking to institutional food?  Besides, there is a hidden special quality about food that is made by someone who loves you.

Two reasons we opted out. 1) As a middle class family, we missed the cut-off, so straddled the line between what we considered affordable. We did not make the cutoff so paid the full price, which amounted to more than what I would normally spend.  We could, however, purchase one lunch a week rather than fully opt out, and so the kids had the chance for an occasional school lunch.

Lol. I think it's less that than (A) My kid is a picky eater (B) leftovers are clutch for everyone in the family (C) it's always cheaper to brown bag it (D) no school around here has food that looks THAT good. Come on.

While I applaud the goal of healthy school lunches, let's get real.  This is a big country.  In rural Colorado, there are school districts that can't afford to be open 5 days a week. Perhaps focusing on nutrition education (by someone with a college degree in nutrition) for everyone should be the goal, starting in elementary school.  As someone who had a career and degrees in nutrition and physiology, I am astonished at how little people know about nutrition.  Even less now in the information age than 20 years ago. People swing from one extreme diet to another.  The NYT even recently had an article about a 90% fat weight loss diet and quoted nutrition researchers.  How can that possibly be healthy in the long term, even if people temporarily lose weight?  Article like that don't  teach people how to eat a good balanced diet or keep the weight off or exercise and even give the impression that it is a healthy diet.  We do know what makes a good diet and people aren't doing it, even if they think they are eating healthy.

So instead of encouraging people to have their children buy school lunch so the school cafeteria can get more money, maybe the focus should be on nutrition education so people know what to pack for school lunch and  are eating healthier at home too.

It's great to hear that school lunches have improved in recent years. I ate school lunch as a kid and mostly liked it, though I was certainly among the few. Yes, but note the non-recyclable Styrofoam trays.  That alone is a good reason to pack the kids' lunch.  What are the school districts thinking?

First, while school lunches are healthier, that doesn't mean they are healthy.  My elementary school child regularly talks about nacho fun lunch (which is a few chips with cheese and salsa), or other fun lunches with no nutritional value.  My middle schoolers can regularly purchase cheese steaks, pizza, chicken fingers, and greasy grilled cheese sandwiches.  Yes, these lunches all come with fruits and vegetables, but not those that taste good - it's canned produce, full of preservatives.  On top of that, the lines are long and the kids have about 20 minutes to get their lunches and eat.
Until we get REALLY serious about healthy lunches, we will continue to pack fresh fruits and veggies, and healthier proteins.  School lunches are an occasional treat.

Because my kids have 20 minutes to eat lunch at school and it takes them 15 minutes to get through the lunch line.  They do recess after lunch so kids have no desire to wait and finish their lunch. Packing their lunch at least gives them a little more time.

Our school district, Houston ISD, has been serving FREE lunches to ALL students since Hurricane Harvey devastated the region. I can't stress enough what peace of mind this has given me, as a mother. I still pack their lunches, but if I forget or they're extra hungry, I know there is a viable (and sometimes tasty) option for them. They even like the breakfast! Houston is a city with a very  poverty rate of over 20%, even higher for children.  Free school lunches change lives!

My daughter's public school gives her 15 minutes to eat lunch, then kicks her out of the cafeteria.  I make her lunch every day because it makes me feel good, but most importantly, because if I didn't,  she would spend her entire lunch time in line to get food and not get to eat

My  mother's lunches were  crazy, sometimes embarrassing, sometimes stinky, oftimes messy......but probably one of my most vivid memories of the love my mother had for me and my siblings.  I would never trade her boiled fish sandwiches, salted egg, sardine or cold meatloaf in foil for anything.   I really prefer my mom to the nanny state.  Others may need the extra dietary help out of need, or parents who are not engaged... but that was not us!   Thanks mom... we love you!
I pack my kids lunch because THAT is NOT what Dallas school lunches look like. But even those have chocolate milk! and lowfat milk?

Quite simply, it is considerably cheaper to pack  lunch than to pay for one.  Many parents cannot afford the daily fee to make sure their child(ren) get fed.

There's more than food quality that keeps kids bringing lunch.  My grandkid got something like 15-20 minutes to eat lunch.   Kids had to go on line for a school lunch and were left with maybe 5 minutes to choke down their food.

Our child packed a lunch because the cafeteria line was so long. That, of course, meant only the free lunch kids “had” to line up in the cafeteria, making them stand out, be inconvenienced, and anyone in line be stigmatized. Sigh. So much to unpack there.

'Food for thought' (no pun intended). Just wondering what happens with all the food available...and not used on time, discarded perhaps. Wouldn't it be prudent for our community to preserve or use what's available, before we look for novel ways to duplicate such an effort?

Well, you are living in a fantasy land if you think the lunches at my local school look like the ones pictured. Pretty sure I will have to pack her lunch indefinitely if I want to keep her from eating chocolate milk. chicken nuggets, and pizza non-stop.

Please, some sensitivity - Hallal deserves consideration. Food that is spiritually healthy is just as important.
Duh! Any meal prepared at home from fresh ingredients is going to better for you and better tasting than even the best school cafeteria meal.
I wish someone would pack my lunch before I head off to work. Anyone?

Parents making the time to pack lunch for their children is an act of love and responsibility.

Some parents belittling school lunches for those who can't afford it is an act of tolerating an irresponsible government and sows the seeds of a class conscious society that can't get its act together.

Dr. Gaddis is right. The consequences of a tiered-school lunch system is that those who can afford to pack lunch do so, leaving those without time and resources dependent on subpar food. And yet, I pack lunches for my kids. Why? Because of the plastic waste in school lunches. The author's idea of good, healthy food differs from my own and I don't think she has a good sense of what is actually served at most schools.

My son says he has 15 minutes to eat lunch which is the main reason he brings his lunch home uneaten.  Let's remember that school is about more than academics.

I packed my own lunches while growing up and did the same for my kids.  We all survived, healthy and not obese.

My small town's public school served vegetables from cans.  Ugh.

My kid stopped eating school lunch because of the lines. One of the things I never see addressed in articles like these, or in any other lamentations over the lousy eating habits of our nation, is the fact that the majority of people in this country don't have access to good fruit. Great article! Lunches at public schools are much healthier these days and accessible to all. They also reduce on plastic and other waste in most cases. Kiddos on free and reduced lunch are better served by those students who aren't when they also participate in the school's lunch service. It reduces stigma and subsidizes those who can't afford it.

My children are teenagers but I pack lunch for them as an expression of my love for them. The lunch is nothing fancy, just left overs or peanut butter and jelly, and they don't eat it half the time- but that okay.
My family all take lunches (to work and school).  Buying is an occasional treat, we do it to save both TIME and money.
Parents pack lunch to save money and to have full control over the ingredients.  I can't believe the question is even asked.

I fully agree (with the disclosure that my child attends Austin ISD and yes, the lunches really are that good) and find that there are even more benefits than what's listed here. When all children eat the school lunch, they learn to try new foods and to eat what's available, instead of always having recourse to what's preferred and familiar. For me as a working parent, high-quality universal school lunches alleviate a lot of headaches.

It's been noted here that standing in line for the food takes half of their lunchtime, and the food is mediocre at best. Sending our kids to school with healthy food we know they will eat is a better option for many of us. I appreciate Op-Ed articles, but I believe the piece would benefit from a counterargument. PG

With all due respect, the writer misses the point -- "You can lead a horse to water, but you can't make him drink." 

Ms. Gaddis wonders why kids who are ineligible for reduced cost lunches bring their own. Perhaps it is because they eat the same sort of food at home their mothers (and fathers!) pack for school. 

As a substitute teacher in a solidly middle class community in Fairfield County, CT, my observation is that cafeteria lunches are heavy in fats and carbohydrates, with piles of pasta and servings of pizza even too large for an adult. Green stuff is minimal. And these "entrees" are complemented with chocolate milk, sweetened juice drinks and cups of processed fruit.

Yes, fresh fruit is available, but much of it is discarded. 

So perhaps what the children are served needs to be changed to provide more protein, more roughage and less low cost, belly filling fats and carbohydrates.

One way to improve what children eat is to teach parents to avoid the center of the supermarket and shop the perimeter for fresh food -- vegetables, fruits, meat, fish and dairy.

Until children are offered nutritionally balanced meals, I applaud the parents who choose healthier lunches than what the US government sees fit to offer.

At the same time I a sorry for children whose meals are free or reduced cost because school meals may be all -- or most of -- what these often food insecure children receive.

While there are significantly healthier choices at school, there are still unhealthy options.  Kids don't always make the best choices.  My 6 year old brings a healthy(ish) packed lunch from home 4 days a week, and give him the option to buy lunch and make his own choices the other day.  I'm a frequent visitor to school and have sat at the table and watched what kids eat, my own included.  He picks the chips and the cookies and the ice cream.  Other kids take their tray loaded with healthy food and toss everything but the bagel.  The cheese pizza is still the favorite.  I'm secretly cheering on the kids that ate the fruit and salad.   We have to keep trying to do better.  Giving kids the options and education to make better choices.  I'm fortunate that I can afford the healthy food at home.  Not all kids have parents that can.  The choices and options of all children matter to everyone.  These are our children's peers, their friends, and will become the community we all share.

I appreciated this perspective. Do you stick with the common shared experience that doesn't deliver what you want or opt out for an option that allows you more control. I hadn't really considered the downside of opting out before. Our kids packed lunches in elementary school because I could give the kids healthier food.  I think one easy change could be to speak up more -- praise the meals that are healthy and complain (nicely) about the ratio of white carbs and cookies.  As with all things, the quality of the common experience will decline if we let it.

The pictures of those lunches look disgusting, despite all the fancy food styling. We still make our high school aged kids lunches daily: A sport top water bottle, carrots, celery or cucumber with a single serve hummus cup, a fruit, a few cookies or chips for snack, and a sandwich. (Today's was tuna, lettuce, tomato on rye bread, but they can also be made from the previous night's dinner).  Our kids are a healthy weight and excel in school.  Also, they don't have cell phones, social media, or play video games and have tons of friends.  (While that last part is not food related, it definitely makes for more well adjusted children.)

My mother gave me lunch money every day, and every day I spent some of it on soda and ice cream and saved the rest. I don’t think I ate a real lunch once the entire 12 years I was in school. And I turned out perfectly fine. I have a law degree and a job and I eat vegetables now by choice.

I applaud the NYC public schools for providing universal free lunch.  It is incredibly important that food be available for all and that no one is shamed with "school lunch debt," a phrase that shouldn't even exist in this country.  The lunches served at my daughter's elementary school however, look nothing like those in the photos presented here.  They are also heavy on meat, which she doesn't eat.  The PB&J sandwiches are prepackaged (wrapped in plastic) with a sort of bread that one of my daughter's classmates told me she wouldn't eat, and she is not the only one.  The lunchroom is also wildly understaffed, with two women doing an incredible job, with the help of parent volunteers when they are there.  Let's face it, everything about public education in this country is undervalued: the teachers and staff, the food, the maintenance of the buildings.  

It's been my NY public school experience so far that everyone (including parents) is working hard and doing their best against formidable odds.  I personally would love to save the time spent making lunch four out of five days a week, but better options would need to be provided for me to make that decision.

I find this article fascinating, mainly because of my memory of terrible school lunches, and my jealousy of what's on offer in Austin.  I guess the saying "Keep Austin Weird" applies on multiple levels.

But I also want to point out that it isn't just mothers that stand to benefit from improved lunch programs.  I'm a single dad.  I pack my two elementary kids' lunches every single day.  I prepare most of our meals at home.  It's a financial necessity because $2.50 per kid per day adds up when your middle-class professional budget is stressed to its limit.  

I know that mothers have traditionally carried the burden of meal planning and prep, and I am so grateful to my own mother for the meals she prepared.  But I can't be the only dad that has taken on the role of nutritionist-chef for his kids.  I recognize that I'm shouting into the void here, but maybe it would be possible to provide just a hint of recognition that some fathers don't subscribe to the Ward Cleaver philosophy of fatherhood.  Sorry, it's been a tough morning getting my kiddos out the door to school on time.

Ha!  When I read the headline I thought this article was going to suggest that kids pack their own lunch, not that they BUY lunch.  

As a parent with 3 kids, buying lunch at school is more expensive than bringing it from home.  And you have more time to eat your packed lunch, as opposed to waiting on line to buy your food, carrying it back to your table and then finally eating.  

I've always wondered why schools are in the restaurant business.  Several private schools that I know of do not serve lunch.  It's expensive and there are a lot of health regulations to comply with.  Not worth the bother.
Well, I have my kids pack because it’s a good lesson in healthy meal prep. School lunch? The healthier line is too long and they only have 30 minutes for lunch.

Wow does this article miss the mark.  It's based purely in a what-if world and every parent I know has to deal in the day-to-day reality of family life - not some ivory tower utopia of which Ms. Gaddis is probably more accustomed. 

Did the author consider the cost of school lunches?  If we signed up for school lunches every day, that's just a drain on us financially, and our son doesn't really care for the food either. That helps no one!  

Another commenter posted what I thought - the headline gave the idea we'd encourage children to pack their own lunch.  That would be a great idea.  
I've packed a healthy lunch for my son, my wife and I for years (and I'm a man - gasp!!!) because it costs far less and I know exactly what we're eating - nutritious food of our choosing.

And I don't feel pressured to make Instagram-worthy lunches, either.  Anyone who does should re-evaluate their priorities.

Your idea regarding a conscientious public investment in high quality universal free school meals is worth a look.  But honestly, that is a far different topic than a parent choosing to pack or buy on a day/week/monthly basis.

It depends on your income, meal preferences and the meals provided by the school. I've yet to see meals like those in the pictures, provided fresh and crisp at a price point that would make it affordable or a good option. FOr those on Free/reduced price- the meals in the picture are most likely better and a better value than home prepared. HOwever I'm not sure that my children (or me when I was a child) would eat those meals based on eating habits. Salad-yes (if fresh)- milk- no-small cut up apple- only in season and crisp- dry pits- no. Chili-never

Buying school lunch and EATING school lunch are VERY different numbers. I should know because I AM a lunch lady at our elementary school. I packed my kids lunch largely due to the very real issue outlined by previous comments about the time constraints. But I can assure you that these healthier meals are ending up in their entirety in the trash. What child doesn’t like Mac n Cheese? For all of those of you advocating healthier choices, I implore you to spend a few days in your school’s cafeteria to audit the results. I would sooner we sacrifice some in fat and salt so that kids eat SOMETHING versus skipping meals altogether.

Can we please stop judging parents? 

Here are some reasons why parents might still pack their kids a lunch:

1. Food allergies that can't be well-accommodated by the school cafeteria. 

2. Their school cafeteria is not one of the ones that have significantly improved.

3. Their kids *still* don't like or won't eat what's on offer. 

And before you get all judgmental about that, please remember that kids on the spectrum and kids with sensory issues may be more acutely sensitive to what they eat than other kids. Wouldn't you rather that the struggling kids are at least well-fed -- even if it means not following Ms. Gaddis's personal opinions?

Also, while childhood obesity is a huge problem, let's not forget that there are kids struggling at the other end of the spectrum -- kids who, for whatever reason, struggle to eat enough and gain weight. Maybe it's because of their ADHD meds. Maybe it's a medical issue. Maybe it's just because they have serious sensory issues around food. Maybe it's because they are one of those "super-tasters" for whom almost everything tastes bad. 

It's great to write an article or opinion piece on how school lunches are improving. But there's just no reason to muddle it with judgement that parents are doing yet *another* thing wrong: namely, packing a lunch for their kids to bring to school.

It isn't only about nutrition.  Is it such a terrible burden for a mother to prepare lunch for her child, when the child can open his lunchbox (are there still lunchboxes?) wondering, what did Mom make for me today?  Why not go all the way:  park the child in a state dormitory, have her fed industrially, and let someone else shoulder the grotesquely heavy burden of raising her and taking care of her and loving her.  Written by an old man who is still grateful for the lunches his mother packed in his Tom Corbett Space Cadet lunchbox.

While my middle school made admirable improvements to it's lunch fare in my last year studying there--real plates and utensils, produce from community garden nextdoor, etc--my high school experience was significantly disappointing. From the  start of lunch to the ending passing period, we received perhaps 25 minutes to take care of all lunchtime activities, including standing in line for lunch (which frequently ran out of most things if you didn't sprint), eating, attending club/sport/class meetings, making up exams, and/or visiting the office. In a school of 2000  students, this was not a particularly functional setup. As a CSF member I also helped serve lunch (student volunteer) at least one week a term, and it was insane--especially given tiny portioning requirements and massive rushes of people. Finally, the food we had was of unreliable quality, be it undercooked or unhealthy, or just completely void of vegetarian (let alone allergy-friendly) options; multiple times foods were labeled as one thing but were something else entirely. Things may be improving piecewise throughout the system, but overall school lunches leave much to be desired.

Food may be better, but the amount of time the kids have for lunch doesn't get them through the lines, seated and eating. Both our kids ask that we pack lunches for them to avoid the long lines. I believe they have less than 20 minutes bell to bell. As the schools pack the schedule, the lunch time is broken into groups, with some kids having lunch as early as 10:30 or as late as 1:00 in order to get them through lunch and their 7-8 classes in a day.

The kids don't have time to get to their lockers, so they must carry all their books and notebooks for the day, including their lunch, which is usually squished among their books. We have tried various containers and healthy choices, but items sitting in their bags for a couple of hours gives you few good choices.

The cooks, the kitchen staff, the kitchen, the cafeteria set-up and the use of pre-paid accounts all seem to be working fine. It's just too much in too little time, and the kids would prefer to talk and catch up then negotiate a slow process.

Is the program for people or people for program? I am not quite sure if I get this logic. I grew up in a culture of bringing lunch to school and sharing with friends. Shouldn't it be up to each parent to decide whether they want to pack school lunch or not? My Chef husband has run school cafeterias and let's say students really don't prefer fancy organic food even if it's offered in cafeteria. At least with home meal, they may be persuaded to eat so. Plus costs for families are less.

I’ve been a school social worker for a decade and I’ve always worked in Title I schools. I’ve dedicated my life to kids & I really appreciate this article. That said, I’m also one of “those moms” — my children receive homemade ramen, wraps, smoothies, organic fruits & veggies, and so on in their lunches. For me, cooking is a beloved hobby and a great stress reliever. It brings me a lot of happiness to think of them enjoying a lovingly home cooked meal during our long days apart (between school & activities, we only see each other for several hours in the evenings.) Just another perspective — I don’t do it for Instagram (I don’t even have an account). My kids do eat at the cafeteria a couple times a month but I won’t stop packing their lunches. For me, it’s too important a gesture of love.

Lunch costs money.  Food from home is cheaper. Combined with the time element ( 20 minutes to go from last class to basement locker to switch books to 4th floor lunchroom then get to next class), lunch line is impractical.  I’m not sure what was served but after a really busy week when I gave my son lunch money, he asked me to go back to packing his lunch for him.

All commentators seem to have landed on the same theme: it takes too long to stand in line and get lunch, and the lunches don't look anything like those shown in the photos. 
The larger point behind these is the structure of the school day and the lack of focus on children's health, with the focus placed on assembly line structure (less than 30 minutes for lunch? Wow) and no accountability at the school and district level for health.

My kids didn't qualify for free or reduced lunch, so we paid for lunch until it became clear that they wouldn't eat it. Then it was pack a lunch and grab a sweet a la carte. Actually saved money, as several have already noted.

I let my kids buy lunch once a week because lunch costs $7.50 each.  We can feed our kids healthier and cheaper meals. I’m all for free lunch for everyone, but don’t try to shame parents who have to budget carefully to provide for health costs, housing, and college about why aren’t they are not using school lunch.

Hmm. My mother told us (in the 1960's) that if we didn't like the school lunches we could pack our own.  We did.  I told my sons (in the '00's and 20-teens) the same thing.  They chose school lunches.

Looking at the comments, it seems that the author is getting a husband lesson I learned many years ago.

Assuming you're relieving a "woman burden" by eliminating some task without asking said woman first is not helpful and will probably be taken as disrespectful, possibly even as an insult.

Want to be helpful? Ask how you can help. Unless she says she doesn't want to be asked because answering is like giving you orders and she doesn't want to be in charge of you. So then the answer to to not ask. But then she may accuse you of not being engaged enough to ask her questions. 
All that leads to the summation of husband lesson #1: You, dear husband, are wrong.
My kids were alloted 20 minutes for lunch in high school, barely giving them time to hastily eat their sandwich from home.   Standing on a cafeteria line was simply not possible.

I've worked in 2 wealthy NJ districts for the last 20 years, and middle school lunch did NOT look like these photos.  The favorite lunch days for most students are spaghetti and meatballs day and taco day.  Pizza is served daily and many choose a slice of that. Lunch ladies tell each child to grab a piece of fresh fruit- much of it goes into the garbage can.

Many well to-do moms drop off high end sushi, designer sandwiches, or store made fancy salads at the front desk, necessitating a phone call into classrooms to come down to the office.  

The 60's peanut butter and jelly sandwiches of my day, when almost everyone was slender, are pretty rare today.

The lunches at my children’s school bear zero resemblance to the pictures. My kids call school lunch “UFO” - unidentifiable food objects. I thought they were being dramatic until I saw some of the lunches when I volunteered at school. It’s low quality food (processed, prepackaged) and not even close to being healthy. And on top of that, the packaging waste is unacceptable - plastic utensils, wrappers, plastic containers. Each meal produces bags and bags of garbage. While it’s free which is important, it’s still terrible food. NYC public schools have not yet figured out how to serve healthy, tasty food.

I'm thrilled the quality of school lunches has apparently improved. Now how about using real plates and dinnerware? Do you have any idea how much trash schools toss on a daily basis because of the school lunches, and breakfasts? Teaching kids to save the planet is a little self-defeating when the school doesn't practice what it teaches. So, until that happens, I encourage families to pack healthy lunches in containers that can be reused. At the same time. get school boards to find ways of using dinnerware the can be washed and cleaned.

I'm wondering if Ms. Gaddis has kids in school. It's not the food quality... it's the amount of time allotted. By the time most kids stand in line and get their food, they have to scramble for a seat, gobble it down and lose equally valuable social time with friends. Perhaps if schools focused on the quality of life - including downtime and recess in the upper grades - instead of just the quality of food, more parents would be willing to buy school lunch.
Montgomery County serves pizza, french fries, and packaged fruit that is not particularly fresh. I'll pack lunch for the whole family because it is higher quality and less expensive.

I would love to know which schools serve the lunches in the pictures.

Real life school canteen food looks nothing like this.  Brown and bruised apples and wilted brown edged salad is more the norm.  

Lets face it - the food is made fresh at some point - but by the time it hits the cafeteria, it is past its best in most cases and is far less appealing than in these pictures.

Nachos, fried chicken sandwich, gluten and gluten with cheese. I wish my son would just have hot lunch at school but, he asks for a lunch box 2 or 3 days a week and I can't blame him when I see the menu.

Growing up in Latin America eating school lunches in elementary school, I was a fit, slim active kid. As soon as we moved back to the US in the late 90’s (foreign service parents) and I entered the 8th grade at a public school teeming with “Cookie Friday” and daily pizza, chicken fried steak with a side of tots and the occasional “healthy” wilted lettuce leaf thrown into a sloppy joe as ‘salad’, I gained 46 pounds in that year. That year alone. We had PE. And this wasn’t just puberty. I was literally on my way to becoming obese thanks to school lunch alone (to address other factors-my parents consistently prepared healthy homemade meals for every other meal, mostly vegetarian). My pediatrician gathered my fat and said I “needed to stop eating so many cakes and sweets” (my parents never brought home or made cakes and sweets). I hit 9th grade, asked my parents to let me pack my own lunches, joined 3 athletic teams, became track captain, swim team captain, lost all the weight and never touched “cookie Friday” again. If anything, the pre-diabetic coma these school lunches were heading me towards  totally backfired and I took so much control back (simply because they were literally plumping us up with fat and hormones like livestock— almost all the kids were fat in that middle school) that I will not even touch anything I don’t prepare myself. Thanks school lunches! You made me so fat, I swung back like a pendulum to nearly having an eating disorder from restricting! Pack. Lunch.

Each lunch shown includes a carton of cow's milk -- a visual message implying that milk is essential to good nutrition.

Do parents really want their children to drink a substance containing hormones from a cow that has recently given birth and is able to provide this commodity because she is no longer feeding her calf? 

Do we really want our children drinking milk that generally contains antibiotics given to cows raised in crowded --and often inhumane--  conditions in feedlots that force their handlers to medicate them because of the threat of disease in these unnatural living situations?

The dairy industry is massively wealthy and influential. That does not mean what they are selling is good for our children.

The author has missed the mark.  I am not feeling pressured to pack instagram worthy organic, local, fair trade meals meals for my kids.  I pack what they will eat and it’s not school lunch.  School lunch options in our district are generally unhealthy (mozzarella sticks, walking tacos, pizza) and inedible.  My kids do not care for them.  Nor do they enjoy standing in long lunch lines that limit their already too short lunch hours.  My elementary school kiddo only has 15 minutes for lunch. Not enough time to stand in line. My MS and HS kids want to eat quickly and escape the loud lunchrooms and rowdy kids.  School lunch is not generally a pleasant experience in most school districts, particularly low funded ones like ours that face overcrowded and under supervised lunch rooms and understaffed cafeteria employees.

The headline of the article made me think the author was going to discuss why we should have children pack their own lunches.  That would have been a better article.  Kids that are empowered to plan their own lunches (school lunch selections or packed) are more likely to eat them, too.

Lots of comments on here and likely this has been mentioned but one of the benefits of sending lunch to school is the opportunity to cut down on waste. We use a lunchbox that does not require us to wrap everything in plastic, foil, bags, etc.

And I tell my kids that's the reason we do it. Its an environmental choice for us.
2.50 a day per lunch with 2 kids is 25 dollars. It may be cheaper to pack lunch if you don't get subsidized.

I always packed my daughter lunch even though I qualified for reduced rate school lunches because she liked selecting the food for her lunches.  School lunches don't offer much for vegetarians.  As my daughter grew older, it was her responsibility to make her lunch.  She now teaches at a university and still packs her own lunch.

While I have been advocating from Day 1 and continue to do so as I serve on the board of my school's PTA and attend all kinds of community and board meetings, lunches in our elementary schools continue to follow the same pattern: Milk (skim or chocolate), a heavy-in-meat or covered-in-cheese (or both) entree, a pale green vegetable, and a sad fruit. I am vegan and although my kids are not, I serve mainly plant-based meals at home. My stomach lurches whenever I forget to send lunch to school.Try as I may, there doesn't seem to be any way to turn that around in my suburban area. So thanks, but no thanks.

Speak for yourself. Here in eastern Mass, the food in my daughter's school is made by a highly suspect local food prep company. Just because it is made locally doesn't mean the food is sourced correctly and the quality is good.

Schools have light years to go in Mass. Imagine rural Tennessee.

For kids on free reduced lunch, the meals at school may be their only meals of the day. All parents should be advocates for making sure school lunches are healthy. The powerful processed food lobby, big donors to politicians and the School Nutrition Association, have profit and cost cutting, not our children’s health at heart.
I always sent my children off to school with a packed lunch. The cost was a big factor. After 38 years of marriage, my husband still takes a packed lunch to work.

While student teaching I ate the cafeteria lunch every day. I gained ten pounds in those six weeks. Once I began teaching I packed my own lunch. Healthier, much more environmentally friendly, less food waste, and a timesaver. The commenters have nailed the problems with school lunch (including the hideous lunchrooms). I hope the author takes the time to read them.
Why? Simple. I know what my children will eat for lunch and I am perfectly capable of making them nutritious.

Lunch is included in our private school tuition. And the lunch hour is a time when the oldest lower school children "biddy" for the kindergartners and first graders by helping them in the lunch line and with their meals at table.  One of the many things private schools do, including small class sizes, that public schools could easily do if only we were willing to pay for it,

I'm still packing lunch for my kids because when I go into the cafeteria the system is all about heating things up in plastic. Bagels for breakfast here in the bagel capitol of the country means individually wrapped bagels shipped in from somewhere and heated so hot the plastic bags bulge into pillows full of steam. There are so many articles about the dangers of heating things in plastic (hormonal, carcinogenic, infertility) and I just don't have the time in my life to try and change the entire food delivery system at my kids public school. Until I know that the way the food is being prepared is as healthy as the food itself I'll stick to what I can guarantee.

I’m packing lunches every day because my kids’ under-funded charter schools has low quality food. The kids hate it but it’s what’s in the budget. I’ve been told of slimy, moldy items showing up. My kids won’t go near it. 

So instead my kids got Columbus turkey (superior to the usual mass market deli brands) on a visually attractive buttered onion roll, good cheddar for the one who likes it. I sliced good Granny Smith apples, of a quality that I would eat myself, so that they can eat it fast, and because it opens up the flavor. Wife rounds it out with an assortment of snacks for the rest of the day.

And we basically gave them a European style meal. Wash rinse repeat for years into the past and years into the future. 

Our own lunches came off that same spousal assembly line. Would most adults want to have the school lunch for their own lunch?  Probably not. That’s why we give them what we do!

I packed my kids’ lunches for many years. They could’ve taken over the responsibility, but I liked to do it, and I always put in a note. Every so often, one would pack my lunch complete with a note for me to enjoy.

My children’s school district serves exclusively fast food-style garbage. I have advocated for improvements, but my phone calls and emails go unanswered. The State Department of Education informed me that as long as a district meets the basic USDA “Smart Snack” guidelines, they have no obligation to improve. By this standard “whole grain” pop-tarts are a perfectly nutritious food to sell to school children.

It is not just the quality of the food that impelled me to pack my kids' lunches; it was also the time allocated to the meal.  When only 20 minutes is allocated for lunch and you have to spend 10 minutes of that 20 minutes in line for food, there is no time to eat the food whether it is nutricious or not.

We send our children with packed lunches because it’s economical, it’s a way of showing that people can make and serve good food from home (which we consider an essential life skill), and, most importantly, it lets us know whether they have consumed sufficient and varied calories during the day. With children on the lower end of the weight curve, it’s essential that we have some sense of what they’ve actually ingested, so we can make up the difference at dinner or before bedtime.
I’m surprised that no one seems to be writing the obvious:  $5-7 a day = $25-35 a week, $100-140 a month, and 1k  a school year.  I pack a lunch because it’s more affordable.

This is a family choice.  There are all kinds of reasons why families may prefer bag lunches: price, religious reasons (kosher, halal, vegetarian, etc), allergies/intolerances).  Once my kids reached middle school, we kept ingredients but they were responsible for putting together their own school lunches.
If one has little time, perhaps one should not be concerned with how a child’s lunch will look on Instagram.

So let me get this straight, middle class kids should buy lunch at school, rather than the lunch made at home, so poorer kids can have school lunches?

If middle class parents want to ensure the quantity, quality, and contents of their child's lunch, they shouldn’t do that because of other kids?

Insane parenting, if you ask me.

I would love to save the time and have my kids buy lunch at school but aside from the fact that school lunches are pretty inedible, they only get 20 minutes for lunch (on a good day). The kids that have to stand in line for a school lunch end up with maybe 10 minutes to eat if they’re lucky before they have to throw away all of their uneaten food.  Most of the kids that stand in line are the ones that could really use the extra time to eat their entire lunch because it might be the most complete meal of their day.  Add extra time for lunch and bring up the quality just a bit and maybe you’ll get more students paying full price.

Given the volume purchases and the subsidies is should cost less to feed children at school than it does pack a lunch. The different that is just food costs while cafeteria workers are paid and you and your children are not. (Although I would suspect in some households there is paid staff to make lunches to send the kids to school with in the Navigator.) 

However I am not sure I would want to eat them. I see so-called "delicious" apples (and not even a whole apple by appearances) on most trays. These are disgusting. The good-for-you salads and sides feature cucumbers with almost zero nutritional value and tomatoes. Both make me violently ill. Was there dressing for that salad?

The point isn't that the school lunch needs to conform to my taste, but that if I were getting those lunches there would be substantial parts of it I couldn't or wouldn't eat. Leaving me hungry, tired, and not getting the nutrition.  Packing a lunch assures that it contains what I or my child can eat. 

And, even if you believe "you just need to get over it and learn to like things you don't" school lunch isn't the place to to do that. It is at home. And you can't over an allergy or something that your system violently reacts to.

School lunch in my district is $2.75 elementary and $3.00 for secondary not counting any extras. That adds up, and with multiple kids, it can be cheaper to pack. The food in my district is not particularly good, either.  The school lunch changes didn't improve overall quality here; we just got nutritional tweaks (whole grain pasta and rolls, 1% milk) and more veggie packs. Today's lunch is chicken nuggets and tomorrow is walking tacos. My kids buy occasionally, but prefer to bring lunch from home. 

(And this article doesn't account for kids with dietary limitations, of whom there are quite a few. Our elementary schools still serve PB&J Uncrustables as an alternate.)

My absolute favorite school lunch memory is being in London in the early 70’s. We lined up for a plastic green bowl filled with meat and potatoes, and then for dessert you went up again and got a bowl of cake with warm pudding poured over it. It was all hot and delicious. I’m sure that would never fly nowadays.

This article reads like it’s written by someone who has never spent a minute in a real public school cafeteria. First, the noisy line for kids to get their lunch means that by the time they’ve filled their tray, they have fewer than 5 minutes to eat. And yes, in my years of teaching, I’ve seen a small effort by schools to introduce healthier food, but by and large, the students choose chocolate milk and tater tots. You know what they say about leading a horse to water. 

Also, the environment in which the food is consumed often feels worse than a prison. The noise, flickering lights, and amount of plastic waste generated is not teaching our children how to have a healthy relationship with food and eating.

As a digression, white suffering through the indignity of lunch duty, I was appalled at the amount of styrofoam waste in my NYC school. I researched it and learned that NYC public schools are the second biggest consumer of styrofoam in the US. To switch to cardboard trays was another 2 cents per tray, which added up to about $30,000 a year for my school. I was told it’s just not possible given the limited budget.

I pack my fourth grader’s lunch because she doesn’t have the time to stand in line for (possibly) a decent school lunch. 10 minutes for lunch isn’t enough, and waiting in line consumes the limited time she has to socialize with friends, also an important part of the school day. Not enough time for eating and playing. Pretty sad.
Why do I pack lunches for my kids?  (well, my kids pack their own lunches...) Because a kid is vegetarian and the vegetarian options are often quite pitiful.

Schools have a way to increase school lunch participation and be an educational wedge between Big Ag and the next generation of all-too-often obese and ill-fed adults: the school garden.

If a school had a small garden in which the students could plant the seeds, till the soil and see the results they would clamor to eat real food both in school and at home.  They would have muscle memory to understand what it requires to grow food and how good real food tastes.

Every part of school could include such a garden in their curriculum.  Math could do calculations on area and volume.  Science could discuss plant genetics.  Health could have a unit on nutrition or reproduction.  Phys Ed could do some of the physical labor to turn the soil.  In high school, a community garden adjacent to the school could encourage students to think beyond themselves to the health of the community and all its members.  Why do a mission trip to the third world when we have poverty here which we could address?

We can plant seeds in the ground and in student's minds at the same time.

As a father, I get a lot of pleasure from helping my kids get their lunches together. I wake up early and make a good breakfast for them, too. The morning is the only time each day that I can really connect with them - being in their early teens. After they get home from school they are always too busy with homework, computer games or whatever have you to more than give a quick hug or kiss. Even dinner isn’t as good of a moment to connect with them.  Their minds are simply elsewhere, overwhelmed with the day. 

Help your kid make her lunch!  Make breakfast for your son and sit with him. Connect. It’s good!

Most kids get thirty minutes lunches, which means that standing in line makes a significant cut in your eating time. Besides, everything is wrapped in plastic, generating so much waste it is mind-boggling. When we arrived in the US I was ready to give it a try until I saw the school menus, which are really lacking in vegetables and are very much fast-food inspired. In France, where we are from, if you eat at school, except for serious health reasons, you have no choice but to eat the cafeteria food. But there's more time, I'd say 45 minutes in the cafeteria, there are real plates and cutlery, and if there is nothing you like, there's always baguette (everything tastes better with baguette). For kids for whom it is the only real meal of the day, it's a chance to eat something warm and substantial out of a real plate. To be clear, when I was growing up, the food was mostly simple (salad, rice or pasta, meat or fish, fruit, yoghurt), not fancy French food. Kids who are used to takeout food would find it 'bad' when it's just simple.

My children attend a highly ranked public school in a wealthy area. I gave up on packing their lunches long ago. They get healthier, fresher food from the cafeteria. I still don’t understand, however, how they expect kids to eat salads and raw veggies without dressing or sauce. I need at least a vinaigrette.

Well, I just sent my kids off to school this morning with packed lunches, as I have done almost every morning of their school careers.  Not Instagram worthy, but reasonably good meals.

I hadn't really thought about this problem before and will make a point of checking out the school lunch options at my local schools.  

Thank you for bringing this to my attention.

Between the mountains of trash being generated, unappetizing food, and long lines during short lunch breaks, my kids much preferred to bring lunch from home.

I will say that during the Obama years, the high school introduced a salad bar. It wasn’t a great salad bar, but at least it was ok when they forgot to pack lunch. Not sure how that’s faring now that Trump has rolled back nutrition regulations.

Parents, feed your children as you deem fit. It is certainly your right to participate in the federally subsidized lunch program (I do, for $4.50 per lunch for a middle schooler), but the assertion that parents have an obligation to do so is preposterous. Parenting choices belong to the individual or couple raising the child.

This notion is wrong on so many levels that I don't know where to begin. So, I'll start at the end. Parents pack lunches because they want to remind their children of their love in the middle of the day surrounded by influences over which they (the parents) have little control. Institutionalized eating cannot do that. I suggest that you (the writer) keep out of our children's lunchboxes and pay more attention to what our nations children's minds are being fed. Home made lunches say "this is who am, where I am from, what my family values."

I took a bag lunch to school made either by my mother or myself. Most of my work career I took a bag lunch. places I worked didn’t have cafeterias. I still do not understand why schools have cafeterias. I don’t care how poor you are, parents can still make bag lunches for their kids. If people can’t afford to take care of their families, they shouldn’t be having kids and the kids should be taken away.

I would love to hear from my fellow conspiracy theorists about whether school lunches are the best delivery vector for child-specific mind control drugs and the relative effectiveness of school guidance counselors.

Packing lunch is the cheapest and most eco-friendly approach- look at the single use plastics on that tray. I still pack my lunch as an adult. It doesn't need to be super fancy, but packing lunch lets you use reusable items and save money that you'd spend on hot lunches

One look at the pictures of school lunches affirms a good decision to bring from home each day. When I went to school in the fifties, and my children in the eighties and nineties, the lunchbox and containers were reused the following day. We know what disposable plastic waste is doing to our planet. Is this the lesson we want to teach?

Looks a bit too instagram-ish. Ol Zuckerberg’s platforms were never much for honesty.

Not sure about the North Austin cuisine shown, but here in South Austin today’s lunch menu is fish mac & cheese or just mac & cheese. My daughter opted for home lunch and I was happy to make it.

My 2nd grader doesn’t like to buy lunch. She likes the food, but the lines are too long and she doesn’t have time to eat. If schools want more kids to participate they need longer lunch periods or more efficient lunch lines.

You clearly have not eaten lunch in my kids' school.  I hate making lunches and would happily buy the school lunch if the choices were better.  In fact, we did do that when they went to a private Montessori preschool that brought in healthful lunches every day.  But now they are in public school, and the amount of sugar and sodium and fried food is awful.  Flavored milk.  Juice.  Tater tots.  Pizza.  Fried this, sugared that.  Nope, not a chance.  My kids eat whole grain, low sugar, low sodium food I buy and pack for them.  Fruits that are not packed in sugar.  Breads and crackers that are whole grain.  Meats that are not full of hormones.  And water.  On the rare occasion I am in the lunchroom, I am horrified by what I see other kids eating.  They need to take away all the unhealthy choices.  There should be no flavored milk, no juice, no candy/cookies, none of it.  Until you do that, the battle is lost.  Especially with little kids.

I agree with the author's argument fully. However, one point that gets overlooked is that most school lunches are not sourced (prepared) in school kitchens, but by third party providers, which districts find to be cheaper. I have a hard believing that anything made by Sysco and "warmed" up in the cafs is better than something made from scratch in the kitchen of the local caf. When I went to school the high school kitchens in our community prepared hot lunches that were then sent to different schools in the district. And of course, what they made in their kitchen was served in their caf. That is how it should be.

This is an easy answer;

When my son eats lunch at school he has noticeable weight gain in a week. When his lunch comes from home this doesn’t happen.  And, no, his home lunches are are flavorful, having just made homemade Swedish meatballs and brown sauce for today.

As a teacher, I always pack my own lunch because I dread having to eat the limp, overcooked, tasteless offerings that my school cafeteria provides.  Like the pictures in the article, the lunches don't necessarily look bad, but they are certainly lacking in the flavor and nutrition department.  
I continue to send my kids to school with lunch because they don't want to eat soggy, unappetizing cafeteria food either.  Not to mention that I can pack healthier lunches for both of them for less than what their school cafeterias charge.

Wow...

Now I am a deterrent to progressive policymakers, low-income employment and my child's health by choosing to prepare lunches at home? I guess we should give up on having the whole family have home-cooked dinners together at the table and just eat/order out to create more employment opportunities.

I am proud that the whole family eats together and our children have learned to cook their own meals. Not just mac and cheese, but healthy, interesting foods from cuisines all over the world.

I am all for free breakfast and lunch for all students, as a measure to ensure that anyone who needs a healthy meal is able to obtain one without stigma, but DON'T tell me that it is my duty to not provide lunch for my children in order to create employment opportunities and strengthen political policy.

I'm not sure how prevalent the online lunch accounts are nationwide, but I'm guessing they are. Parents put money into the accounts and the kids then buy what they want at lunchtime. Besides the "healthier" options, this also includes the opportunity to buy pizza, chips, french fries, cookies, etc. for lunch. You can imagine what many of the kids are buying when those options are out there too.

To interject a little humour and nostalgia from my Brooklyn upbringing in the 50s: I remember mom packing a "healthy" lunch of a salami sandwich on white or italian bread (no lettuce) . Then there was  Anthony who was obese (because he had a gland problem?) - his typical lunch was a overstuffed meatball hero on a foot long piece of Italian  bread. My treat was getting an extra quarter on Fridays to buy a bowl of chop suey (Thinking back I can't imagine what went into it but at least there were vegetables).

Universal free lunch (and breakfast!) came to NYC while my kids were in elementary.  It is the most convenient thing ever. Truly a gift to logistically challenged working parents.  My kids have gradually shifted to preferring the school food to bringing from home, so that even when we send something it tends to come back.

When I went off to first grade in 1955, my mother handed me a brown paper sack with a deli meat sandwich, a fruit and a piece of Danish.  I just retired and I was still carrying a brown sack for lunch most days with a deli meat sandwich, fruit and baked chips of some sort and a couple of cookies. 

As a father, kick the stereotype, I did what my mother had done and made sack lunches for my three children.  I was strongly told to skip on Chic Fil-a day.  Since each child’s lunch  was slightly different, I would write their names on their sacks and make decorations out of their letters.  It was not about the quality of the lunches, it was not about the cost, it was about family.
