The only reason I pack my child’s lunch is because lunch time at school is so short that she would spend almost half of the allotted lunch time standing in line, and be left with not enough time to eat and visit with friends. Schools need to create healthy schedules as well as lunches.

My daughter is a senior in high school.  She’s a vegetarian. Her high school’s only vegetarian options are a pre-packaged salad, which she doesn’t like, or greasy cheese pizza. 

She brings her own lunch, usually a hummus and sprout roll-up, and cut melon. 

If there were a decent variety of vegetarian options she’d buy her lunch.

Saying this is good food does not make it so. What these staged pictures seem to show are variations on 1) milk, 2) bread/french fries, 3) salad greens, and 4) a few pieces of fruit. One assumes there is a piece of meat in there somewhere. This is not a sustaining, nutrient-packed meal. A whole foods, vegetarian lunch box would be so much better: steady, balanced energy release for the rest of the day. And food prepared by someone who loves you is nourishing on an emotional level, as well.
It costs pennies for my daughters lunch to be made at home. That's why we still make her lunch at home (well, we make her make it...)

Kudos to the Austin school for healthier fare. Too bad they are serving all of it on disposable ware. I can imagine the school board discussion. "Shall we pay for dishwashing or stiff future generations with the bill?"

Agree with most of the commentary so far, so I have little to add.   Though I will chime in that this particular father is very engaged in food prep for his boys---they went off with "Super Greens" soup (kale, arugula, spinach), freshly made this morning.

The off-topic observation I have is the unexpected highlighting of the tone-deafness of progressive politics these days.  Are they really calling it "Universal Free Lunch"?  Regardless of the merits of the proposal, I certainly hope not.  I can only imagine the field day that the conservative propaganda echo chamber would have with that one.

Although school lunch quality improved under First Lady Michelle Obama's tutelage, it is now being degraded by an administration beholden to the food industry and set to reverse each and every policy that the best administration in my lifetime established. We sent our daughters to school with healthy food, enjoy cooking quality meals together, and delight in their healthy food choices as young adults. Yes, it took some time each day, but they knew that we put effort into making them lunch, and became upset when their classmates tossed their lunches in the trash.  Perhaps the school lunch program needs restructuring, where it is led by a non-partisan administrator in conjunction with a nutritionist, and not subject to the changing whims of the present administration.

Our local school district has opted to provide free breakfast and lunch to ALL students, regardless of family income. My kids at have opted to brown bag lunch for years, although they often eat breakfast at school. I am sure there are schools in the U.S. that still have operating kitchens, but the food in our district is prepared at a central location off-site and trucked in to the schools.  When I was a kid, every school had real kitchens with real "lunch ladies" preparing real, hot, and appetizing lunches every day.  Until and unless taxpayers are willing to fund something better for children (such as the European models mentioned elsewhere in the comments), the school lunch table will continue to be yet another reflection of income inequality at which middle and high income kids are eating organic stuff from Whole Foods, and kids whose families are low income are eating warmed over pizza and fries.

My kids' biggest issue with buying lunch is the long line and short time left to eat after waiting in it.  I would be happy to stop packing a lunch, and they generally like the school lunch food otherwise.

The author’s intentions are positive I suppose; however telling parents that their desire to pack lunches for their kids is preventing other kids from having grass fed beef burgers and other organic specialties is a bit precious. The father who cared and fed his kids home made lunches makes a great point that caring for your kids by making them lunch is a better use of a parents time than any leisure activity. And all it requires if for the parent to get up 10 minutes earlier and shop on the weekend.

Is it really necessary to stick to gender stereotypes about who makes the lunches? (Mostly) women may be statistically accurate, but that fact is unimportant to this story. Some families don’t have “wives” or mothers while others have fathers that reach beyond traditional roles. Parents parent children so how about just sticking with that?

I worked for many years on small organic farms. I care about organic standards. I mostly purchase organic food, from local farms when in season. I also grow a big garden, have backyard chickens and have many fruit trees.

Why would I want to support big agri-business when there are alternatives?
Not to mention the enormous amount of disposables that would not end up in our landfills should more people start packing lunch from home. I disagree with the main premise of this article.

My college had a mandatory food program for students living on campus. The majority of students were more or less required to live on campus. You had three different meal plans to choose from at varying price points. Assistance for lower income students and medical exemptions of course. Thus, we had a very healthy and robust school food program.

I still got sick of the cafeteria food eventually. The dining hall inevitably became the meal option of last resort.

The same thing was true in grade school. Whether homemade or school bought, there was a standard menu rotation that simply becomes unappealing over time. The problem is so much worse as a child though because you have so much less control over your food decisions. I never told my parents about the meals I gave or traded away.

One other consideration, never underestimate a parent's capacity for nostalgia. Particularly among young children bagged lunches become a sort of love language. You're preparing a (supposedly) beloved meal as compensation for the time you can't spend with the child. The ritual gets emotionally entangled. Outsourcing the task feels cold and utilitarian even when the decision makes perfect sense.

Besides, how else can you introduce children to the meals your parents made? I fully plan to torture any progeny with the canned roast beef sandwiches my parents would make. Builds character. For the record, I haven't eaten canned roast beef since grade school.

To the point of the article, each to their own. If parents want to show love for their children by packing lunch, I think that's wonderful. When I did it, I occasionally put a little note in it. Irritatingly, the article had to get the dig in against men. I was a single dad who raised my kids because their mother couldn't, and I always cooked wholesome and healthy meals for my kids while working three jobs. Although my youngest is now a freshman in college, my kids love my cooking and still remember it fondly. I do not remember school lunch being that great, and I know the Trump administration is doing everything they can to make it worse. Time spent loving and caring for your children is time well spent even if it cuts into your leisure time.

In a diverse district, the middle class has to pay for everything out of pocket.  I pay for books for all nonelective classes - i.e. AP lit.   I pay for sports and music by providing transportation and funding thru the booster activities. I pay for AP coursework online because the school won't offer honors Science.  Now the author wants me to pay for a low quality processed carb & wheat loaded lunch that is mostly going into the trash can, a lunch my child can't eat without incurring enough allergic reactions that I'll have to pay hundreds out of pocket for the doctor visits ? Thanks, I'll stick to my high quality unprocessed choices and seasonal fresh produce. Childen need good nutrition.   And the milk is still going to be local - I'm not interested in the local farmers being put out of business, their children are classmates of mine.

 How about a small tax on every international cash transfer from the district - that should pay for the program out of the stream of under the table dollars leaving the district. How about the property tax on a single family home that houses three families changes to reflect that it is a multifamily rather than a single family?  Fair share.

"Yet the progress K-12 schools have made toward serving healthier and more appetizing lunches may stall unless more middle- and upper-middle-class parents can be persuaded to let their kids buy lunch at school. Without greater participation from children paying for lunch, local school districts will lack the funds to maintain the gains in quality."

I already pay more than my share in taxes to subsidise schools, why would I want to pay for lunch when I can make it at home.  My kids don't even want to eat school lunches, they want leftovers that I make at home.  I cook, I prepare food on weekends, they start their day with fruit shakes and eggs and oatmeal. My kids have no more interest in taking a school lunch than going to McDonalds.  They don't drink soda, they have no interest in fast food, but they love some warm spinach salad and a great roast beef sandwich.

Born in 1951, I grew up in a segregated Long Beach, California housing project and packed my own lunch the night before school. We were allowed 4 cookies, no matter the size, one slice of lunch meat on white bread, and a small bag of chips decanted from a larger bag. By the time I reached Junior high, it was a complete embarrassment to brown bag it. The home EC. teacher had us bring our typical lunch for a grade. My mother controlled all resources and had me bring an apple and a peanut butter sandwich. The teacher let me know this was wholly inadequate. When I informed my mother, she basically informed me that the teacher knew nothing of what she was taking about. This entire column and comments are as if from another universe.

Unfortunately, in most public schools in Washington DC area provide junk lunch, not even worth feeding it to a dog, and while private schools provide lunch it is expensive and in some schools students cannot pay for it with cash.

Judging parents who are caring for their children?  "Women spending time preparing meals?  (Fathers do that too...).  Despite setbacks, Trumps french fries mandate - it's all healthy - really?  I'm going to back away slowly and try to forget I read this.

I have always marveled at the food offered by schools to kids in France, the Netherlands, and other countries in Europe. Fresh and healthy food for all. As for packing lunches, starting at about age nine, they can, and ought to pack their own.

I seem to be the only one here so far whose child has qualified for free lunch. It was a few years ago but the students in our district who get free lunch may not choose any of the “junk” such as ice cream, fries or chips. Those items were on sale for students who bought their lunch. My daughter used to like the pizza until they made it more healthy. All of the food tasted awful to her and she was forced to take an apple or a banana which she promptly threw in the garbage because it looked bruised. The lines were so long she didn’t get time to eat the food and she was called out for having free lunch in front of her friends even though the policy is not to. The free lunch also entitles students to a free SAT and helps with graduation fees. This is a wonderful thing but high school students don’t want their friends to know and school personnel don’t always keep this secret. I will also add that some cafeteria workers come to work while they have a cold or the flu.

Dads could pack lunches too. But all kidding aside, if your school is serving better lunches, parents, let your kids buy lunch. It's easier for you and fine for them. It's not Fruit Roll-Ups. And don't kind yourselves about the qualities of meals you pack, I have seen plenty of chips, fruit by the foot etc, in school lunches in the 14 years I worked in independent schools.

Those who advocate having kids eat school meals should try those meals themselves; the quality and quantity can vary substantially from school to school and city to city.

It is also important to look at what the calorie, salt, sugar and additive loads of these meals are.

We can’t expect much from trump who called public schools, government schools! Lol. He has no idea public schools are run by towns aided by state. My real estate taxes in this pricey suburb of Boston pays for teachers salaries and school resources.

My son is a high school science teacher in the poorest district in nyc. He is proud of what he does every single day, which is excite students to embrace science. It’s hard many students come from hardships beyond description but still they make it to school and it’s cause to celebrate so he celebrates each day his classroom is full. When students eat right they perform optimum in class. The school is their haven, they leave behind their domestic baggage when they enter the school and celebrate each day as new.

I imagined a different conclusion to the title: Why are you still packing lunch for your kids ... when they are capable of packing their own? 

As a middle school teacher, I see too many parents doing too many things for their children. And I see too many helpless children expecting service from the adults around them.

Giving our children the skills to pack their own lunches is a great step toward instilling independence and responsibility. More parents should offer their kids this chance to learn how to get organized, plan, and care for themselves in this small way, regardless of what the lunch lady is offering.

You may have theoretical reasons for thinking that school cafeteria lunch is good.  Many students know otherwise. If the food were to become acceptable to the majority of students, they would eat it.  But in a system without choice, there is little incentive to improve the quality, whatever federal programs may be doing. You are basically arguing in favor of forcing students to eat food they don't like -- easy, because they can't fight back.  I suggest you eat the school lunch for a few weeks.

Our school lunches still have enough junk on the menu that our kid only makes the worst choices if we let him buy lunch.  If we pack him a healthy lunch he eats it.  Examples of school lunch junk he buys are nachos with cheese, fries, and grape juice.  We live in a suburb with many involved nutrition conscious parents, but their influence only goes so far, and junk food always manages to win a place in the cafeteria.

“Mothers, in particular, are pressured to be the perfect parent: Most of the advice on social media and parenting blogs is directed at them.”

It looks like the Times is adding to this pressure. If mothers make a nice lunch, the author implies that they’re only doing it to show off on Instagram, and if they don’t buy lunch from the school, the whole system will collapse, causing poor children to lose out yet again.

Every student in our district is eligible for free lunch and breakfast this year, but my kids will not eat food prepared at school. 

Two reasons: 

First, lunch time is about 24 minutes long and the wait time between receiving food and being able to eat it chews up (pun intended) most of the lunch period. 

Second, they find, and have always found, the food at school unappetizing.

Finally while a large number of students in our district qualify as low-income, we — along with a significant number of my children’s schoolmates — are not. We can afford to pay for lunch should my kids opt to purchase it. I feel uncomfortable accepting for free something meant to benefit others when I have the means to pay.

I packed my kid's lunches because I wanted to, and it gave them what they wanted, while I could control that they got food they'd actually eat.

Other people gave their kids lunch money and that is fine, too. 

A packed lunch meant they did not spend most of their short lunch break in line. It allowed them in high school to eat quickly and use the time to go elsewhere in the school  and get work done for clubs or projects. It allowed them to take a necessary course during traditional lunch times, and eat lunch on a short break.

Please don't turn the lunchroom into yet another political parent trap. We do what we need to do, for reasons that have to do with our lives, our schedules, our kids - not an overarching need to justify a already completely justifiable federal lunch program.

Huh? An article telling parents to NOT be involved with the kid's education and health? Just leave it up to the Government? C'mon. I'm not about to let a committee of experts feed my kids in the hopes that things have "progressed."

No way. I make ALL the lunches in my home. That way, I know what my family eats. We save money- affluent folks become affluent by being smart with money, $4/day for school lunch vs. $1 for packed is quite a savings. 

Likewise, I am ensured of my kid's health. In a time of obesity in kids, this is critical. 

Lastly, talking to friends who work in schools, they all comment on the amount of food waste- usually the "healthy" veggies. So if you care about Climate Change, make your kid a lunch they will eat and not waste!

My first thought when I saw this article was that it would be about encouraging children’s involvement in lunch-making. 

Once I read this article, I laughed. Not only is the food served at the local schools disgusting-looking (think mystery meat) and unhealthy (lots of fries), but lunch time is so short that children who eat the school lunch barely have time to eat it. As in, under ten minutes. There are many components to a healthy school lunch, and sufficient time to eat is one of them.

If a Democrat is elected president next fall and high nutritional standards for school lunches are maintained or raised it may make sense to encourage more children to buy lunch.  Unfortunately Trump plans to weaken requirements.
The argument that making school lunches is an undue burden on parents (mostly mothers) is very weak.  Once parents are in the habit of preparing daily lunches for their children they can do it very quickly.  Once the children are old enough to help, participating in the preparation can be a good parent/child experience in many ways.
The urgent need is for the government (federal/state/local) to see providing nutritious lunches and, where necessary,  breakfasts, to school children who need them as part of its responsibility--along with healthcare for all.

School lunch wear I work in Rhode Island has improved — this year thanks to a new director with more imagination in the kitchen. However, the lunch program generates a tremendous amount of waste including hundreds of styrofoam trays and plastic utensils daily. This is a problem. 

Most students who bring “lunch” from home bring an array of plastic packets including chips, cookies, crackers, and fruit candy. They bring so-called sports drinks and don’t drink milk. If they have change they buy dip ‘n dots. That strategy is clearly unhealthy and also generates tons of trash. The whole situation needs to change if we are to have strong, healthy adults in a livable clean environment.

Bc I use reusable containers and don’t want all the styrofoam in the landfills.  I would be more than happy if they used real dishes but it is one of my goals to not use take out containers, to-go coffee, plastic bags etc.  This includes styrofoam.

While I understand Dr. Gaddis's argument, the burden for supporting healthy food options for children should not fall just on middle-class parents who have an active instagram account.  

The nation needs to make the health and well being (and education) of all of our children, regardless of their income, a high priority.  And if that means subsidizing high-quality meals for those who can't afford them, we should be more than willing to do that.  

These children are our future.  We should not let a stingy administration or a "super mom," who enjoys packing their children's lunch or wants to control what they eat, undermine the quality of what is available to all children at lunchtime.

This article bases its content on the changes to the school lunch program of 2010, and barely mentions the recent changes coming from the trump administration.
Yes, the 2010 did change school lunches for the better.  However….

Or make the order of the primaries random. Literally pull the states out of a hate to determine the order of primaries to be held on 5 or 6 dates spread from February through May or June. Do the hat 5 times for the next 5 presidential elections, so the order will be different each time, but set long in advance. Then after 5 elections, assess how the new system works. The system we have now is beyond stupid, and destructive. Make it random.

Or you hold an actual, countrywide election.  In two tiers.  First all the candidates, then the two best scoring.  And then you focus on winning the actual Presidential election.

This long drawn out and increasingly acrimonious process is making only Trump and his cohorts happy.  And that would be the case regardless of who the GOP opponent is.

Moreover, unbelievably and suicidally, it becomes ever harder to imagine that the eventual Democratic nominee from the current approach would get the wholehearted support of the other candidates, let alone their disappointed supporters.

"Imagine a world in which the Democrats’ first contests gave them a fuller, more nuanced portrait of whom the full Democratic base supports."

Amen to that!  What Democrats are doing is essentially handing over decisions about their party to Democrats in largely Republican states, in terms of attitude, ethnicity, and population centers.  

At the very least, you need some coastal states with large urban population centers thrown into the mix.

One more thing: get rid of the caucuses altogether and make primaries uniform: one vote for each state resident, for those who care to participate.  Just like the final general election.  Because why should candidates be penalized by a complicated system or low turnout in high school gyms when most primaries take place all day?

I am sick and tired of reading (well-meant) suggestions of how some national level change should be imposed on the primary election for president.  There is no mechanism for doing so.  Constitutionally administration of elections is a function of the states.  There is no administration of elections at the federal level. Congress can set minimum standards, e.g. the Voting Rights Act of 1965.  The naional political party organizations (RNC, DNC, etc.) can set minimum standards for how delegates to their conventions are chosen.

In the case of caucuses the process is administered by the state political party.

In the case of primaries they are administered by the state government election authority (BOE) under laws enacted by, and subject to change by, the state legislature and governor.  That is where dates are set and issues such as extended voting days and mail voting are determined.  The state BOE  
manages the process of selecting equipment, training and paying poll workers, arranging for polling places, and then the process of tabulating the results.  Some of this may be delegated to county or more local BOEs.

We can and should push at the state level for better voting laws.  At present that means electing Democratic legislatures and governors.

1 primary day for the country on the Tuesday after Memorial Day, and extend the national holiday so everyone gets a 4 day weekend.  And, while we are at it, make the General Election in November a national holiday too.  And no more caucuses ever again.
